image.altText: Mitchell Starc holds both arms in the air and appeals towards the umpire

items.synopsis: Steve Smith brings up his 32nd Test hundred as Australia is bowled out for 416 on the second morning of the second Ashes Test at Lord's. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Australia chasing wickets after lunch on day two at Lord's

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: England will be thrilled to see their openers make it through that awkward period, but conceding 77 runs in 90 minutes this morning is tough sledding. They'll have to start again after some scrummy scran, and so too shall we. See you back here in 40 minutes.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: LUNCH: England 0-13 (Crawley 6, Duckett 7)

props.alt: Mitchell Starc shouts with his arms in the air as he appeals for a wicket.

children.content: England will be thrilled to see their openers make it through that awkward period, but conceding 77 runs in 90 minutes this morning is tough sledding.
They'll have to start again after some scrummy scran, and so too shall we.
See you back here in 40 minutes.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hazlewood slashes a wide one to Joe Root at first slip and thus ends Australia's first innings at Lord's. Fair to say Australia left a few runs on the table considering how many batters got scores without reaching three figures, but still, scoring more than 400 after being put in to bat by the opposition is a massive win. For England, it's a worrying sign from this bowling attack that looked pedestrian for large chunks in favourable conditions. Now it's up to the willow-wielders to take advantage of what look like better batting conditions, with openers Zak Crawley and Ben Duckett facing an awkward 15-minute window before lunch.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia is all out for 416

children.content: Hazlewood slashes a wide one to Joe Root at first slip and thus ends Australia's first innings at Lord's.

Fair to say Australia left a few runs on the table considering how many batters got scores without reaching three figures, but still, scoring more than 400 after being put in to bat by the opposition is a massive win.

props.alt: Nathan Lyon completes a swing of the bat as England bowler Ollie Robinson looks on.

children.content: For England, it's a worrying sign from this bowling attack that looked pedestrian for large chunks in favourable conditions.
Now it's up to the willow-wielders to take advantage of what look like better batting conditions, with openers Zak Crawley and Ben Duckett facing an awkward 15-minute window before lunch.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Smith flashed at a wide one and sent an edge rocketing to gully, where Ben Duckett took a sharp chance to send Smith on his way for 110. This is a man who's famous for his concentration, but it doesn't seem like a coincidence that that dismissal came seemingly out of nowhere right after the drinks break. Still time for Josh Tongue to take another five-fa.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Smith finally falls and it's Tongue again!

props.alt: Steve Smith raises his bat as he walks off thed field in a Test match.

children.content: Smith flashed at a wide one and sent an edge rocketing to gully, where Ben Duckett took a sharp chance to send Smith on his way for 110.
This is a man who's famous for his concentration, but it doesn't seem like a coincidence that that dismissal came seemingly out of nowhere right after the drinks break.
Still time for Josh Tongue to take another five-fa.

image.altText: A woman speaks in front of several microphones

items.synopsis: The 688 page Operation Keppel report released by ICAC covered a lot of ground. Here are the key findings.

title.children: 'I am the boss, even when you're the premier': Key findings from the Gladys Berejiklian ICAC report

image.altText: A police officer points at a woman near a car

items.synopsis: A SA police officer accused of the aggravated assault of an intoxicated young woman tells a court he struck her twice using the soft, bottom-part of his first, not his knuckles, as the prosecution alleged.

title.children: Police officer seen hitting woman in court video after she stopped grabbing him

image.altText: A crowd, some standing, some sitting, some waving Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags behind a gate

items.synopsis: South Australia has delayed the introduction of its state-based Voice to Parliament, just months from the referendum to decide whether to create a national Voice.

title.children: South Australia delays Voice to Parliament elections over 'confusion' with national vote

image.altText: A picture of a smiling woman with grey hair and glasses inset in a circle with flowers on it

items.synopsis: SA Police suspect two elderly people, who died one year apart, may have been murdered by the same person after abnormalities in both of their toxicology reports were found.

title.children: 'We believe both were murdered': Police open major crime investigation into deaths of elderly couple

image.altText: Martin Duku walking outside a court building wearing a suit and glasses

items.synopsis: A former South Australian police officer who indecently assaulted two women in Port Augusta has been sentenced to 15 months' prison, despite concerns from his lawyer it would not be safe for him.

title.children: Former cop jailed for indecent assault despite safety concerns

image.altText: A Cronulla Sharks NRL player passes the ball to his right against St George Illawarra Drgaons.

items.synopsis: Ben Hunt has spent the week in the headlines but it was opposite number Nicho Hynes who stole the show as Cronulla eased to a 52-16 NRL thrashing of troubled St George Illawarra.

title.children: Sharks thrash Dragons as Hynes stars in local derby

image.altText: A fluffy dog with blue eyes sits on the ground, as someone uses a syrienge to inject medicine into its mouth.

items.synopsis: The corporate regulator allows dozens of pet insurance policies to go back on the market after issuing a ban that lasted less than a day.

title.children: Pet insurance ban lifted after Woolworths, RSPCA, Guide Dogs and more pull policies

image.altText: Steps leading down to a beach with a small patch of sand and ocean

items.synopsis: Coastal erosion is washing sand away from some of Adelaide's most popular beaches at a rapid pace, with a state government review still months away from completion.

title.children: No turning of the tide in battle to protect Adelaide's beaches from coastal erosion

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Victoria Cross recipient Ben Roberts-Smith lost one of the most expensive legal cases in Australian history this month. Now he has agreed to pay the legal costs incurred by the defendants.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith agrees to pay defamation case legal costs, which could run into tens of millions

image.altText: Gladys Berejiklian close up

items.synopsis: The former NSW premier thanks her supporters and says the ICAC report is with her legal team.

title.children: Berejiklian releases statement after ICAC finds she took part in corrupt conduct

image.altText: Police officer confronts man at Strathpine

items.synopsis: The man was told to remain in the car, but repeatedly kicked the door into the officer in an attempt to leave it, police said.

title.children: Man who was repeatedly punched by police officer following car crash charged

image.altText: A car on the street

items.synopsis: Deputy Commissioner Murray Smalpage says Alice Springs' crime rate has fallen to its lowest level in four years — but NT Police are yet to back that up.

title.children: 'It doesn't stack up': NT Police fail to back up claim Alice Springs crime rate at lowest point in years

image.altText: A closeup of debris from the Titan submersible pictured under a blue tarp, tied down with yellow straps.

items.synopsis: Debris from OceanGate's tourist submersible Titan, that was lost with five passengers aboard, has been recovered and returned to the mainland in Canada. What happens next?

title.children: What is an implosion? What happens with the debris of the Titan submersible? And more questions answered

image.altText: Road workers stand on an empty highway that is cut off with traffic cones

items.synopsis: The girl was allegedly driving a car when it crashed into a truck on the Hume Highway near Alexandersons Road at about 8:20am.

title.children: Fourteen-year-old girl charged after fatal crash in Victoria

image.altText: A police car and police tape is seen in front of a house

items.synopsis: A psychiatrist tells WA's Supreme Court a man who killed his parents was so mentally ill, he believed he had "no other option" and was doing what was "morally right".

title.children: 'They're both in their beds dead': Court hears man felt killing his parents was 'morally right'

image.altText: Richard Marles with short grey hair wearing grey suit holds a plaque with Manasseh Sogavare in a black suit

items.synopsis: Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles says Australia is willing to continue providing troops and police support to Solomon Islands.

title.children: Marles commits to ongoing defence, security support for Solomon Islands

image.altText: A group of PNG women and babies sitting on a verandah

items.synopsis: A group of bandits that kidnapped an Australian professor in the PNG Highlands appears to have struck again, this time snatching and assaulting a group of women and girls. Warning: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: The PNG gang that kidnapped an Australian professor may now be unleashing new horrors on teen girls

image.altText: An older man with greying light hair and glasses wearing a suit and tie stands in front of a blue Reserve Bank of Australia wall

items.synopsis: The treasurer will soon announce the fate of the RBA governor and economists are split over whether Philip Lowe should stay until rates settle or make way for new blood to guide the bank through turbulent economic times ahead.

title.children: Many economists say Philip Lowe made a 'huge error'. So will he keep his job?

image.altText: Danny and Michael sitting down looking down at a screen

items.synopsis: With youthful energy and a quintessentially Australian soundtrack, the debut film from the RackaRacka brothers hits all the right notes.

title.children: Australian 'in a way that doesn't feel gross': Lifelong dream comes true for Adelaide filmmakers

image.altText: Close up of dog behind fence with a shelter in the background.

items.synopsis: A regional animal rescue needs to find an extra $60,000 in donations after one of its funding agreements came to an end.

title.children: This shelter says it will keep rescuing animals despite losing funding. But they can't do it alone

image.altText: A woman with short hair and glasses putting up a closed sign in a door window

items.synopsis: Ange Lawrie opened her cafe in South Australia's south-east just before interest rates started rising. It is closing this week after falling sales — a situation facing eateries around Australia as winter bites.

title.children: Hospitality businesses hit hard as interest rates rise while temperatures plummet

image.altText: Two Russian military men in army gear gesturing,

items.synopsis: A New York Times report, based on a US intelligence briefing, said General Sergei Surovikin had advance knowledge of the mutiny and that Russian authorities were checking if he was complicit.

title.children: Rumours swirl about fate of Russia's top generals who have not been seen in public since aborted mercenary mutiny

image.altText: A woman smiling, looking into the camera

items.synopsis: A Supreme Court jury has been told Hunter woman Danielle Easey was killed after making threats against people in the local drug scene.

title.children: Danielle Easey was allegedly murdered after 'the crack ran out and she lost it', jury told

image.altText: Giles sits cross-legged on the floor of his apartment. He uses one hand to push his head towards his shoulder.

items.synopsis: Australian researchers call for an end to the use of opioids to treat acute back and neck pain after finding they are no more effective than a placebo.

title.children: Giles was prescribed opioids for his back pain. A new study suggests the drugs were pointless

image.altText: Two teenage girls with long, dark, braided hair. Their backs are to the lens.

items.synopsis: Melinda Scash took a leave of absence when an independent workplace review into Highview College was launched earlier this month. She has stepped down ahead of the findings being delivered.

title.children: Victorian principal accused of unfair treatment over students' braided hair resigns

image.altText: Illustration of black holes and gravitational waves

items.synopsis: Astronomers around the world have found the first hints of elusive fingerprint of gravitational waves created by monster black holes at the centre of galaxies.

title.children: 'It's like an ocean': Space-time is warped by a background of gravitational waves, and astronomers may have detected it for the first time

image.altText: A low cloud hanging over Uluru in June 2023

items.synopsis: It's a forecast that sounds unbelievable, but the Bureau of Meteorology says there's "the most outside chance" of snowfall on the cards for central Australia this weekend.

title.children: Snow in the NT this weekend? It's not impossible. Here's what it would take

image.altText: marine creature living in shell eats fish

items.synopsis: Deadly cone snails reared from eggs in a laboratory aquarium uncover a potential treasure trove of new venoms for drug development.

title.children: Deadly marine creature could hold the secret to development of new drugs

image.altText: Celine Cremer smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Tasmania Police searching for missing Belgian tourist Celine Cremer say they have received expert medical advice the weather conditions she is lost in for at least nine days are "not survivable".

title.children: 'Not survivable': Growing concerns for Belgian tourist Celine Cremer as Tasmanian weather deteriorates

image.altText: Shiree smiles, looking at a sunset over the bush, wearing a hat.

items.synopsis: Shiree spent hours in the freezing bush of Namadgi National Park, waiting for help after injuring her ankle. Now she's among those advocating for good preparation before heading out for a bushwalk.

title.children: Shiree's run ended with a dislocated ankle and an 11-hour wait in the snow for rescue

image.altText: Geelong Grammar School

items.synopsis: Only Victorian schools with annual fees of $15,000 or more are set to lose their payroll tax exemption from July next year — a measure which will affect the 60 top private schools.

title.children: Victorian government releases list of private schools to face payroll tax

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and glasses and a man with a bear in a flood-damaged house

items.synopsis: When the waters receded after the record-breaking flood in Lismore, three people were found dead inside homes — but only one of those houses is classified as a high-risk priority for government buybacks.

title.children: Two homes where people died in February 2022 floods not eligible for buyback

image.altText: A man in a cowboy hat leans down and fixes an engine

items.synopsis: Known for his "cheeky smile" and "quick wit", 32-year-old Tom Grey died in a plane crash last year that was "not considered survivable" by Australian Transport and Safety Bureau investigators.

title.children: Bird strike caused Chinchilla plane crash that killed 'lovable' pilot, safety bureau finds

image.altText: Taylor Swift smiling while holding an armful of awards.

items.synopsis: The maths are simple. Most Taylor Swift fans wanting tickets to her Australian shows will miss out, writes Paul Crosby.

title.children: Got Bad Blood because you couldn't get a T-Swift ticket? Understanding the maths behind it may help
